title: Travis Barker and Kourtney Kardashian toured Salem
author: Megan Johnson
bullets: Travis Barker and Kourtney Kardashian toured Salem, spotting cobblestone streets and landmarks like Old Town Hall and the Bewitched Sculpture.
The couple, in town for Blink-182's concert, joined a Witch City Walking Tour with their son Rocky and a bodyguard.
During their Salem visit, they dined at Gulu-Gulu Cafe with no fanfare, engaging with few people as Barker took a photo with a fan.

title: Trump says ‘with a high degree of certainty’ that suspect in Charlie Kirk killing has been caught
author: The Associated Press
bullets: President Trump announced a suspect in Charlie Kirk's killing has been captured, turned in by a minister.
Charlie Kirk was targeted and shot at Utah Valley University during a political debate on September 10, 2025.
Authorities had released images and videos of the suspect, receiving over 7,000 tips before the capture.

title: Your new Cape house could be a 245-square-foot cottage in Eastham for $259,000
author: Megan Johnson
bullets: A 245-square-foot cottage in Eastham, built in 1940, is listed for $259,000 by Compass and the Day-Logan Group.
The cottage features a pine and beamed interior, a kitchenette, and an outdoor shower; part of a 10-unit colony.
Homeowner association fee is $135 per quarter; located near Eastham town landing and Fort Hill, a National Seashore site.

title: A Newburyport teen’s body was unidentified for 33 years. Now, his aunt and a cold-case aficionado want to bring him home.
author: Sana Muneer
bullets: Anthony Angelli Rea was identified using DNA testing, resolving his 33-year-old missing person's case from Newburyport.
Maya Ambrose, a cold-case enthusiast, assisted Rea's aunt Carolann Angelli with organizing efforts to retrieve and bury Rea's remains.
A GoFundMe campaign raised nearly $3,000 to cover costs of returning Rea's remains to his family for burial beside relatives.

title: Did you follow the local news this week? Take our Greater Boston news quiz.
author: Peter Chianca
bullets: Boston.com's news quiz features Hasbro, Aroldis Chapman, Arthur T. Demoulas, Matt Damon, and Ben Affleck.
The quiz aims to test readers' knowledge on recent trending stories in Greater Boston.
Peter Chianca, Boston.com's general assignment editor, developed the quiz with AI assistance.

title: Amid opt-out rumors, Sam Kennedy says Alex Bregman ‘wants to be here’ with Red Sox
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Alex Bregman has an opt-out option in his Red Sox contract after the 2025 season.
ESPN's Jeff Passan reported Bregman might opt out for a long-term contract this offseason.
Red Sox president Sam Kennedy says Bregman and the team are focused on current season goals.

title: Bill Belichick says in new book that Tom Brady made ‘right decision’ to leave Patriots in 2020
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Bill Belichick stated that Tom Brady made the right choice leaving the Patriots due to team rebuilding challenges.
Brady left New England in 2020, signing with Tampa Bay Buccaneers and winning a Super Bowl that season.
Belichick faced criticism for poor drafts and failed succession plans, leading to his departure from the Patriots in 2024.

title: West Boylston town administrator fired after Trump flag dispute sues town
author: Molly Farrar
bullets: James Ryan sues West Boylston for $1.3 million after being fired over a dispute involving a Trump flag.
Ryan claims wrongful termination linked to conflict with Police Chief Minnich over political signage regulations.
Ryan's firing followed a Select Board vote; West Boylston and Minnich haven’t commented on the lawsuit.

title: 18-year-old injured in R.I. after lighting himself on fire for TikTok challenge
author: Darin Zullo
bullets: An 18-year-old was hospitalized with severe burns after a TikTok challenge in North Smithfield, R.I.
The challenge involved lighting himself on fire with gasoline and jumping into the Slatersville Reservoir.
No charges have been filed, though the stunt occurred on private property, and the youth's name remains undisclosed.

title: ‘Fear and uncertainty’: Everett officials cancel Hispanic Heritage Month festival amid ICE crackdown
author: Darin Zullo
bullets: Everett cancels Fiesta Del Rio Hispanic Heritage Month event citing local ICE raids causing community fear.
The canceled event was planned for Sept. 20 to feature live music, art, and local food vendors.
Mayor Carlo DeMaria pledged future efforts to celebrate city diversity despite the current cancellation.
